awd_abstract_narration:
DMREF: SusChEM: Heterovalent Ternary Nitride Semiconductors and Mixed Ternary-Binary Heterostructures

Non-technical Description: The binary nitride semiconductors gallium nitride, indium nitride and aluminum nitride and their alloys have found important commercial applications in optoelectronics and high-power electronics, but indium and gallium are expensive and scarce, and flexibility in the design and control of the properties of devices based upon mixtures of just these three compounds is limited. There is growing interest in the much larger, but much less well-studied, family of ternary nitride semiconductors that include, for example, zinc germanium nitride and zinc tin nitride, formed by replacing the group III binary element with equal proportions of group II and group IV elements.  Many of these dozens of potentially useful materials are composed entirely of earth-abundant, inexpensive, and benign elements. The increased complexity of the ternary nitrides, and the greater number of materials and combinations, is expected to lead to new materials properties and more flexibility in their design. This project will accelerate research on this new family of materials by combining efforts in theoretical calculations and modeling of devices and properties with synthesis and characterization focused on an important subset of these materials. Dissemination of new and archived results via an interactive website-accessed database available freely to the community will foster a growing network among research groups that will accelerate progress toward understanding and controlling the properties of these materials and developing new applications for them.
 
Technical Description: The research will focus on developing growth and doping methods for ZnGeN2 and ZnGeN2-GaN mixed ternary-binary heterostructures by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). This focus will take strategic advantage of the mature technology for GaN growth and doping, earlier demonstrations of successful growth of ZnGeN2 by MOCVD, the close lattice mismatch of the two materials, and their close optimized growth conditions. The focus additionally will take advantage of the theoretically predicted large band offset between the two materials, which have similar band gaps in the near-ultraviolet, in the design and synthesis of the interesting heterostructure and alloy systems that result from this situation. The theoretical and experimental results, combined with the development of a network, based upon the publicly accessible database website for research groups working in this area, will lay the foundation for expanding research efforts on this large family of materials.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was the development of heterovalent ternary nitride semiconductors and their alloys with the binary nitrides for optoelectronic applications. The specific materials chosen for this study, ZnGeN2 and ZnSnN2, are closely related to the binary nitride semiconductors GaN, AlN and InN, which form the materials basis for the revolution in lighting technology through the adoption of efficient, low cost LED lighting. It was recently proposed that combining the heterovalent nitride semiconductors with the binary semiconductors in novel device designs could enable efficient nitride LEDs in the green to red wavelengths, making possible even more efficient white light LEDs based upon direct emission from the nitride material, rather than with phosphors, as is the current case. In addition, ZnSnN2 is of interest for photovoltaics, because it is composed entirely of abundant, nontoxic and inexpensive materials, and has a band gap well matched for single junction photocells.

"Heterovalent" refers to the situation where cations of two difference valences (in this case, valence II and IV) replace the valence III cations in the binary nitrides. Ideally the valence II and valence IV cations are arranged in an ordered fashion so that each nitrogen is surrounded tetrahedrally by two group II and two group IV elements, thereby locally satisfying bonding constraints, referred to as the ?octet rule?.  However, antisite defects, or a valence II atom on a valence IV site, and vice versa, can readily occur, and control of disorder in the cation sublattice as well as the more complex defect physics present both challenges and opportunities. These complexities can lead to additional tunability of the band gap, and thereby the emission wavelength, by tuning the disorder.  They also afford opportunities for doping, such as variations in stoichiometry and a broader range of defect physics, that are not available in the binary nitrides.

Some of the main experimental achievements were the successful development of growth recipes for smooth-surface, high-crystalline-quality, stoichiometric thin films by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) for ZnGeN2, ZnSnN2 and ZnGeN2-GaN alloys and heterostructures through optimization of the growth parameters, temperature, gas flows and substrate choice, in a custom-designed MOCVD growth chamber. Epitaxial growth was achieved both on GaN templates and on sapphire substrates. Epitaxial layers of ZnGeN2 of the order of 1 nanometer thick were inserted into InGaN quantum wells; this is a required step for the realization of some of the novel device designs. Synthesis of the alloys of ZnGeN2 and ZnSnN2 with GaN proved to have wider growth windows than for the respective pure heterovalent ternary nitrides. This result is significant because it is important to match the optimal growth conditions for the quantum wells and the heterovalent ternary insertion layers. Complexes of antisite defects closely related to the alloy disorder in ZnGeN2 were identified to be among the prevalent point defects by depth-resolved cathodoluminescence and surface photovoltage measurements. Growth of the mixed ZnGeN2-GaN alloy near 50 % composition was achieved after prediction of its stability and properties as part of the theoretical part of the grant and is an example of the DMREF strategy of accelerating materials development by closing the loop between theory and experiment. Measurements of the band offset confirmed a large (~1.5 eV) type-II offset at the GaN-ZnGeN2 interface, with the ZnGeN2 valence band above that of GaN, as predicted by the theory group.

The theoretical knowledge base of the family of II-IV-N2 semiconductors was expanded by predicting fundamental band structure, phonon and band offset properties with Cd, Mg and Be as the group II elements and Si, Ge, and Sn as the group IV elements. These calculations will form the basis for future exploration of this materials family.  They allow for the design of improved materials with specific wavelength targets in light emitting diodes, notably additional opportunities in the green and amber wavelengths, and in the deeper ultraviolet ranges.  Computational studies of the point defects and prospects for n- and p-type doping were carried out for ZnGeN2 and were critical in the experimental identification of defects in this material, another example of closing the loop between theory and experiment in the spirit of the DMREF program.

Several graduate students participated in interdisciplinary research with both computational and experimental aspects. Three graduate students received their Ph.D.s under this program. This project paved the way for technological innovations in more efficient light-emitting diodes by expanding the choice of materials in heterostructure devices, and in addition contributed to both the experimental and theoretical understanding of these materials for a broader range of potential applications.
